A[i] = 1 1 1 1  Mapping I/O Identities to SSLOs
      1:  procedure MAPPER(IOIID, IOClasses, SSLOs, thresh)
        2:      L set S be an arr with len IOClasses.len * SSLOs.len
        3:      for IOClass = IOClasses do
          4:          for SSLO = SSLOs do
            5:             f(- fitness(IOID,IOClass)
            6:             c(- convergence(IOClass,SSLO) )
            7:             S[IOClass,SSLO] <- f*c
          8:             end for
          9:          end for
        10:        return highest-ranked(SSLO, IOClass) pair in S
      11:  end procedure

<!-- end procedure -->

    ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    {
        "SSLO": {
            "name": "read-large-heavy-sequential-mpiio",
            "performance guarantees": {
                "write bandwidth": "2.302232e+3 MB/s", // [1, 1e+4]
                "read bandwidth": "4.187593e+3 MB/s", // [1e+2, 1e+4]
                "mixed bandwidth": "2.791729e+3 MB/s", // [1e+2, 1e+4]
                "operation (latency)": "5e-6 % sec", // [1e-7, 1e-5]
                "metadata operations per second": 5.184896e-1 // [1e-3, 1e+1]
            },
            "access pattern": {
                "random write performance sensitivity": 0.33, // [0.24, 0.45]
                "random read performance sensitivity": 0.36, // [0.124, 0.48]
                "small read request performance sensitivity": 0.7, // [0.8, 0.8]
                "small write request performance sensitivity": 0.6 // [0.5, 0.7]
            },
            "semantics": {
                "posix": true,
                "data encryption": false,
                "data replication": false,
                "data compression": false,
                "data representation": "file" // ["file", "nosql", "rdsbms", "kvs"]          require
            }
        }
    }

    Fig. 5: An example of an SSLO, including storage data categories

figures.caption: Fig. 1: LuxIO High-Level Architecture
figures.description:
The image appears to be a graphical representation of data flow or process mapping involving several blocks with text and arrows between them, simulating a system or workflow. At the top left corner, there is a block labeled "Fitness Matrix" with icons that seem to represent different physical activities or metrics such as weight, height, BMI (Body Mass Index), etc. Below this, there are boxes connected by arrows depicting a sequence of events starting from "Identity" and moving through stages described as classification, fitness matrix, fitness assessment, workflow SLA (Service Level Agreement) construction, workflow SLO (Service Level Objective) calculation, and fitness data processing.

To the left of the blocks, there are two additional boxes labeled, at the top "0/5 1/2 1/3 Authentication" with a graph depicting a success rate from zero to one on an XY axis. The second box below it contains an icon representing a person and text that says "Welcome new fitness member."

On the right side of the flowchart, there are more blocks indicating steps such as "SSO (Single Sign On)" with "Fitness Matrix", "Deployment", "Implement", "Consulting", "Workflow", and "Deployment", then referencing "Luxio Data Pipeline", "Welcome new fitness member", and "Deployment".

Additional text visible in the image includes a classification of fitness data into categories such as identity, welcome new fitness member, authentication, SSO, deployment, implementation, consulting, and workflow. There is also mention of data validation and "data integration".

The style of the image is diagrammatic or flowchart-like, often used in software development, process engineering, or organizational planning to convey the structure of a system's processes. The visual elements include arrows indicating directionality of the process, text labels, and icons that suggest specific activities or components such as fitness evaluations, user authentication, data processing, and construction stages.

The text "Deployment", "Identity", "Welcome new fitness member", "Authentication", and "Workflow" are repeated multiple times, indicating iterative processes or a feedback loop in the workflow depicted. The color scheme includes shades of blue, white, and grey, which is common for technical or conceptual diagrams to denote distinct parts of a process.

figures.caption: Fig. 2: Application I/O Behavior Modeling (1-3)
figures.description:
The image displays a screenshot of a computer interface with a flowchart and text, predominantly focused on statistical analysis, specifically related to sales. The background is white with various shades of blue, orange, and green, and it's a composite of different diagrams placed next to each other.

In the left side of the image, there is an extensive flowchart labeled "Unofficial_Build_v1." This chart includes a series of nodes and arrows indicating steps in a process, possibly software construction or implementation. The nodes are labeled with items such as "Node_2563," "Node_3874," and actions like "Trace: job.exec();" which suggest coding operations.

Next to the flowchart, on the right side of the interface, there is a table titled "Statistical Analysis." The table appears to be a results interface for analyzing the performance or data patterns from sales operations. It lists several parameters like "Total Sales," "Unique Traffic," and others with corresponding numerical values such as "453267," "9150816," and "1574."

Below this table, there's a smaller chart showing two bar graphs side by side. The left graph is labeled "Fitness," indicating some sort of fitness metric or function related to the sales process. The right bar graph is under the title "Traffic" and has numerical values corresponding to traffic-related statistics.

The interface includes various elements like input fields for writing code, a section showing different filesystems paths ("C:/Users/Public/Documents/data_flow_chart"), which suggests an operating system environment. There's also a button labeled "Read File," indicating that the software has functionality to read data from files.

In the bottom right corner of the image, there is a small diagram with multiple pie charts under the title "VOI Traffic Analyzer." These charts seem to represent different segments or channels related to traffic within the system.

The overall context of the interface suggests it is for managing and analyzing various aspects of sales operations using mathematical formulas, possibly in a technical or software development context.

figures.caption: Fig. 3: Example I/O Identity, VPIC simulation
figures.description:
This is a screenshot of a computer interface displaying a shell or command-line window, showcasing a running Python script. The script output includes various lines of text and numbers that seem to be displaying a table or summary of benchmark tests. The text contains columns with headers like `VIPCLASS`, `NAME`, `READ_BYTES`, `WRITE_BYTES`, along with numerical data below them, likely quantifying some form of performance metrics related to virtual memory allocation in a classifier system (as suggested by the `VIPCLASS` header).

The table includes information such as "1078 bytes" for READ_BYTES and "29.4 bytes" for WRITE_BYTES, with corresponding row numbers and class or category names, indicating that the results are perhaps being compared across different classes in a model. Other text indicates filesystem paths and other system commands related to memory usage and benchmarking ("mkdir", "cd", possibly other file or directory creation and navigation commands).

At the top of the image, there is a software package label "Ubuntu 18.04 LTS" suggesting that this is likely running on Ubuntu version 18.04. The screenshot shows a terminal prompt with lines of output from a script or command-line tool, including numerical values and a directory structure, which together suggest the results of some kind of benchmarking performance test for a machine learning model or software program running under Ubuntu Linux operating system.

figures.caption: Fig. 6: LuxIO Deployment Construction
figures.description:
The image is a screenshot of a website or computer application depicting a schematic diagram with various components connected to "SLO". Below are the key details that can be identified:

1. At the top, there are three icons representing different roles or processes: `DEVELOPMENT CONSTRUCTOR`, `RESOURCE MODELS`, and `APPLICATION MODELS`.

2. SLO (Single Ownership Location) is connected to two different types of entities:
   - Resource models, which include four entries: Application Models, Demand models, Data models, Software Models, where the first three are connected directly and Software Models is connected indirectly via Resource models.
   - Application models, which contain four applications: `Infrastructure as a Service`, `Storage Provisioner`, `Interface to the SSD`, and `Software Deployment in CI/CD`. The `Storage Provisioner` application has two connections; one direct and one indirect through `Infrastructure as a Service`.

3. Below the diagram, there is an array of icons representing different elements or features within the system:
   - "Deck" with no further details about what it represents.
   - A chart with various colors (red, yellow, blue) and numbers (1-8) ranging from [0-16], likely representing some sort of status or metrics. The numbers next to each bar are not in English. It is unclear what criteria they represent due to the context of the image.

4. Below the chart, there is a list with one entry: `Resources for Deployment`. The list shows that `Storage Provisioner` and `Interface to the SSD` have been deployed using CI/CD.

5. In the bottom left corner, there are two notifications or messages: one for `New Devices` (9) and another for `Network Devices` (16).

The image also features a lot of text, which isn't fully legible, but it appears to be a mix of English and possibly a script language based on the presence of non-English characters. Due to the quality and resolution of the image, some information may not be accurately represented or visible.

The image is a digital composite showing three pie charts with their corresponding key words at the top and percentages corresponding to each chart. Each chart contains segments filled with shades of blue indicating different amounts of votes or contributions. A legend in the top left corner illustrates how to interpret these colors, which represent various job titles or processes contributing to a collective pool, likely data related to a company or team.

The text "PROVIDING A NEW JOB" is present at the top of each chart, with corresponding percentages: 54% at the top, 81% in the middle, and 32% at the bottom. These numbers suggest that these sectors contribute different proportions to new job provision.

The first pie chart on the left has segments labeled "PROCESSING", "DEVELOPING INSTRUCTOR", "LOADING MACHINES", and others. The second chart in the middle has segments labeled with specific processes like "PREPARING ITEMS FOR SHIPMENT", "DELIVERING TO CUSTOMERS", "BATCH OPERATIONS", etc., though some segments are too small to be legible. The third chart on the right shows a range of professions such as "LOADING MACHINES" and "DEVELOPING INSTRUCTOR", with percentages reflecting their contribution to job provision.

At the bottom, there's a circular diagram with a red arrow pointing upward, signifying an increase in jobs provided by loading machines. The number 16 is highlighted in this diagram, which seems to be representing some form of statistical data or progress tracker. The total at the top right corner states "PROJECTING A NEW JOB PROVIDING A NEW JOB PROGRAM", and there are pie charts showing how many new job offerings are projected versus actual versus those that resulted in actual jobs, with various percentages such as 91%, 54%, 60% for these groups respectively.

The image appears to be a summary or dashboard display meant to convey the impact of different initiatives on job generation within an organization. Please note that due to the resolution and angle of the image, some details are difficult to discern accurately. The use of shades of blue suggests a positive trend or achievement in each area.

The image depicts a bar chart, which primarily showcases statistics related to web traffic and reads data. To the left of the chart is a vertical axis labeled with "Revenue," ranging from 0 to 12 with increments of 6, and indicates that the starting value of revenue is 0 and it increases up to 12. Adjacent to this, on the right, is a horizontal axis labeled with "% Improvement" ranging from -4 to 82, with 0 on the right side representing the baseline. The bars are color-coded in blue for positive percentages of improvement and red for negative ones. Atop the vertical axis, there is text, although it's not entirely legible, but it seems related to some form of cost or spending metric compared to revenue (as indicated by the "Revenue" label).

Overlaying this bar chart are a few key elements:
1. A box containing the chart's title: "Write & Read."
2. Text inside the box indicating different strategies or conditions: "[Write Read]," "Balance (White Skull)," "Confusion Type," and others, each suggesting variations in how text is used or viewed. These might refer to types of content or how it is presented.
3. A small, circular icon resembling a barbell below the chart, which is an informal mathematical representation often associated with mean value or statistical variance. The icons represent numerical values that are not visible in this description.
4. Two red dots and one additional icon above the bars represent some other form of data point or measurement metric, but without more context or information about the scale or source, it remains unclear what they specifically signify. The positioning of these elements indicates a relationship between the revenue metric and the percentages of improvement across different conditions.

The image is educational in nature, possibly from a presentation or document regarding business effectiveness, web traffic strategies, or statistical analysis methods.

The image appears to be a screenshot of a database spreadsheet. The interface is colorful with headers at the top that say "Sites," "IP Address," "Status," "Upload Speed(Mbit/sec)," "Max Download Speed (Mbit/sec)," "Data Loss (Packets)," "CPU Utilization," "Uptime (days)."

The main body of the spreadsheet is populated with information pertaining to various sites. Each row represents a different site, with the leftmost column presumably listing the names. The IP address and status columns are partially visible, showing numerical values which represent IP addresses and some sort of status indicator.

There's also an "Upload Speed" and "Download Speed" indicating speed measurements with "5 Mbit/sec" as the highest value for upload and a lower value for download under "Status." The "Data Loss (Packets)" is shown as "0" for most entries, with one entry showing a value of "96." "CPU Utilization" displays percentages ranging from 4 to 5. Under "Uptime (days)," the values range from "N/A" to different durations in days and hours.

The bottom part of the image shows additional data under headings like "File Type," "Size(MB)," "Last Completed," "Start Time (mm/dd/2018)," with specific entries such as "7-zip" for File Type, "2.15 MB" for Size, and a date and time indicating the file was last completed. The spreadsheet contains numerical values in columns under these headings.

The interface suggests that this is an analytical tool likely used to monitor network performance metrics across different servers or sites, with various data points such as IP addresses, performance statistics, and uptime information for each entity listed. There's also a row at the bottom that lists "5" file types.

figures.caption: (e) End-to-end evaluations of LuxIO service. Separated into ENZO, VPIC+BDCATS, and HACC workloads
figures.description:
The image displays a colorful line graph that illustrates the performance of various sports teams over time. Each team is represented by a different colored line, and the teams are labeled at the bottom by their abbreviations: "ENSO," "PFC," "WGC," "Cats," and "KVW." The x-axis represents the number of weeks in time (up to "16"), while the y-axis shows the value in euros, indicated as '€.' Each line graph illustrates a different category of weekly statistics:

- "Développeur SSD 45k M": This likely refers to "Developer Storage Drive 45 kilobytes Megabyte" and it is shown in blue. It shows fluctuations around the 40,000 mark, suggesting a varying cost or performance metric for this category.
- "Cryptomneso": Labeled with '€10.5k M' and shown in pink, it illustrates a weekly cost or performance metric within a budget of €10,500 megabytes. This line remains fairly stable but has some spikes that could indicate fluctuations in performance or cost.
- "Mémoire SSD 8GB": This blue line shows fluctuations around the '8GB' mark, indicating the weekly cost or performance metric for a memory system of 8 gigabytes. There are notable spikes at weeks 5 and 11, which might indicate significant events or results in those weeks for this category.
- "VMware": This is represented by orange and appears to have the highest value throughout the graph. The line shows a consistent upward trend over most of the time span depicted.
- "PME MEMORY X6": Illustrated in black, it also has spikes at weeks 5, 9, and 12, but overall maintains a steady increase.

In addition to the graphs, there are three numerical values presented in the top left corner: "8," "14," and "30." These could represent quantities of data storage in megabytes or gigabytes, with "8" being at the beginning of the span shown and "30" representing a range, but without more context, their exact meaning is unclear.

Please note that this description is based on the visual elements present and does not include any speculative or assumed information.

figures.caption: Fig. 10: Aggregated runtime of different resource sharing models. Serial means waiting to run on the same resources, Parallel means sharing resources, Partition means running with resource partitioning, and Sharing means running with LuxIO interference staggering and resource sharing policies.
figures.description:
The image displays a graph with various bars that seem to represent data points over time. Each bar is labeled with different software names such as "VIPC," "Wine," "MVS," and others. These labels suggest that the graph might be related to performance data for different hardware components or systems. Additionally, there are horizontal bars at the bottom labeled like a stock portfolio with names like "LUXXIO," "WHO'S TURN," etc., which could indicate that this graph is tracking some kind of financial or resource allocation.

A yellow arrow on the left side of the data track indicates an event or change, potentially labeled as "start." There is also a label indicating a time period at the bottom left, "Exce Time" (which might be a misspelling for "Execute Time"). The line chart appears to show fluctuations in the performance metric over the duration of that period.

In the foreground, there's an image thumbnail with other software and files like "Wine," "MVS," and possibly more hidden by the overlay of the graph. This suggests that the image might have been taken from a screenshot or a computer program interface.

Lastly, there is text on top right and bottom left corners indicating numbers next to bars at certain time intervals labeled as "5," "10," "20," "30," and "40 minutes." These could represent different speeds, workloads, or levels of performance at these respective time periods.

The image seems to convey a technical subject matter, possibly related to software benchmarking or monitoring of computer hardware or systems performance over time.
